review.title: A Fuzzy Syllogistic Reasoning Schema for Generalized Quantifiers
review.abstract: In this paper, a new approximate syllogistic reasoning schema is described that expands some of the approaches expounded in the literature into two ways: (i) a number of different types of quantifiers (logical, absolute, proportional, comparative and exception) taken from Theory of Generalized Quantifiers and similarity quantifiers, taken from statistics, are considered and (ii) any number of premises can be taken into account within the reasoning process. Furthermore, a systematic reasoning procedure to solve the syllogism is also proposed, interpreting it as an equivalent mathematical optimization problem, where the premises constitute the constraints of the searching space for the quantifier in the conclusion.

metadata.title: A Fuzzy Syllogistic Reasoning Schema for Generalized Quantifiers

sections.text: This paper describes a new approximate syllogistic argumentation scheme that expands some of the approaches presented in the literature in two ways: (i) a number of different types of quantification (logical, absolute, proportional, comparative, and exception) taken from the theory of generalized quantifiers and similarity quantifiers from statistics are taken into account, and (ii) any number of premises can be taken into account in the reasoning process. Furthermore, a systematic reasoning method for solving syllogism is proposed, which is interpreted as an equivalent mathematical optimization problem, where the premises represent the limitations of the search space for the quantifier in the conclusion.Keywords: unclear syllogism, blurred quantifier, harmless thinking

sections.heading: 3.2. General inference schema for syllogistic reasoning
sections.text: The main feature of deductive thinking, however, is to derive new information, a conclusion, from the statements that constitute the premises of the argument. Syllogism, a kind of deductive conclusion, is based on the relationship between the propositions and their cardinalities. Therefore, the reasoning process is directly linked to the classical distribution problem [25], that is, how the elements of the referential proposition fulfill the properties or concepts in the statements. Thus, from this point of view, each of the premises of syllogism is a limitation that limits the distribution, and the conclusion is another limitation that must be compatible with the distribution described in the premises. The summary of this interpretation and the following conclusion [11] support us in transforming the syllogistic argument problem into an equivalent optimization problem that consists of calculating the extreme quantifiers of concluding.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: We have formulated a general approach to syllogistic thinking that overcomes the limitation of the number of premises and is compatible with the TGQ, allowing us to manage new types of quantifiers that have not previously been considered in the literature. In addition, we show a way to turn the argumentation problem with binary quantified statements into a mathematical optimization problem in order to obtain the conclusions of syllogism. The approach can also manage different types of quantification, both crisp and vague. This model is currently implemented as a software library that is capable of managing all the quantifiers described in the paper. As a future work, we aim to expand our method of managing different quantifiers within the same syllogism and include new quantifiers of more than two (ternary and quaternary) activities. Another relevant topic that can be taken into account is logistical management and formulating information or implementing contextual reasoning.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, a new approximate syllogistic reasoning schema is described that expands some of the approaches expounded in the literature into two ways: (i) a number of different types of quantifiers (logical, absolute, proportional, comparative and exception) taken from Theory of Generalized Quantifiers and similarity quantifiers, taken from statistics, are considered and (ii) any number of premises can be taken into account within the reasoning process. Furthermore, a systematic reasoning procedure to solve the syllogism is also proposed, interpreting it as an equivalent mathematical optimization problem, where the premises constitute the constraints of the searching space for the quantifier in the conclusion.
